docs.title: Home
docs.text: geronimo is a minimal and easy-to-learn Python library for your quick and dirty everday math calculations, especially regarding high-dimensional geometry calculations.

docs.title: Get started
docs.text: Read the instructions on how to install geronimo, or start right off by reading the documentation of the library's classes.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
from geronimo.geometry.point import Point
from geronimo.geometry.vector import Vector

# define points in three-dimensional space:
p0 = Point([0, 0, 0])   # (works with higher dimensions too!)
p1 = Point([8, 4, 2])

# create a vector from the points:
v0 = Vector.from_points(p0, p1)

# get the length of a vector:
print(v0.length())  # ≈ 9.165

# use pure Python math syntax for operations:
v1, v2 = v0 * 0.25, v0.normalize()

print(v1.length(), v2.length()) # ≈ 2.291, 1.0

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This page will teach you about the ways to install the geronimo library in your project or environment.

docs.title: pip
docs.text:
To install geronimo, you can simply use pip on any newer Python version (>= 3.10):

pip install geronimo

docs.title: Manual
docs.text:
You may also clone the repo manually and use it in an interactive shell if you just want to mess around with it.

git clone https://github.com/mags0ft/geronimo.git
cd geronimo
python3 -i -c "import geronimo"

docs.title: dimensions() -> int

docs.title: geronimo.util.fibonacci(n: int) -> int cached
docs.text:
Returns the nth number in the Fibonacci series, starting to count at zero. Only works for the positive Fibonacci series. Uses caching to be more efficient.

So fib(0) = 1, fib(1) = 1, fib(2) = 2, fib(3) = 3, fib(4) = 5, ...

docs.title: geronimo.util.greatest_common_divisor(a: int, b: int) -> int cached
docs.text: Uses the iterative modern Euclidean algorithm to quickly find the greatest common divisor for two integers, a and b.

docs.title: geronimo.geometry.vector.Vector
docs.text: Generic class to represent a vector in an n-dimensional space.

docs.title: __init__(values: list[float] | None = None, dimensions: int = 3)
docs.text: Initialize a new vector. If no values are given, fill it with n zeroes, where n is the number of dimensions (default: 3).

docs.title: from_points(origin: Point, tip: Point) -> Vector staticmethod
docs.text: Constructs a new Vector from two given points, the origin of the vector and its tip (e.g. target, where it points to).

docs.title: length() -> float
docs.text: Get the length of the vector.

docs.title: __add__(other: Vector) -> Vector
docs.text: Adds two vectors together.

docs.title: __sub__(other: Vector) -> Vector
docs.text: Subtracts two vectors from each other.

docs.title: __mul__(other: Vector | float | int) -> Vector | float
docs.text:
__mul__(other: Vector) -> float

Compute the dot product of two vectors or scale the vector by a scalar.

docs.title: __repr__() -> str
docs.text: Representation of the vector.

docs.title: __str__() -> str
docs.text: Representation of the vector as a string.

docs.title: is_perpendicular(other: Vector) -> bool
docs.text: Check if two vectors are perpendicular to each other.

docs.title: is_parallel(other: Vector) -> bool
docs.text: Check if two given vectors are parallel.

docs.title: get_scalar(other: Vector, check_uniform_scalar: bool = True) -> float
docs.text:
Gets the scalar λ (also known as k or r) for two given vectors. If check_uniform_scalar is set to True, the function will check if the two vectors actually have a uniform scalar λ before returning it, otherwise raising a ValueError.

It is recommended to leave check_uniform_scalar set to True at the expense of slightly more computational effort.

docs.title: dimensions() -> int
docs.text: Get the dimensionality of the vector.

docs.title: normalize() -> Vector
docs.text: Normalise the vector and return the result. Out-of-place.
